section.title: Orthogonal complements and the matrix transpose

introduction.p: We've now seen how the dot product enables us to determine the angle between two vectors and, more specifically, when two vectors are orthogonal. Moving forward, we will explore how the orthogonality condition simplifies many common tasks, such as expressing a vector as a linear combination of a given set of vectors.

This section introduces the notion of an orthogonal complement, the set of vectors each of which is orthogonal to a prescribed subspace. We'll also find a way to describe dot products using matrix products, which allows us to study orthogonality using many of the tools for understanding linear systems that we developed earlier.

subsection.title: Orthogonal complements
subsection.p: The preview activity presented us with a vector \vvec and led us through the process of describing all the vectors orthogonal to \vvec. Notice that the set of scalar multiples of \vvec describes a line L, a 1-dimensional subspace of \real^2. We then described a second line consisting of all the vectors orthogonal to \vvec. Notice that every vector on this line is orthogonal to every vector on the line L. We call this new line the orthogonal complement of L and denote it by L^\perp. The lines L and L^\perp are illustrated on the left of .

figure.caption: On the left is a line L and its orthogonal complement L^\perp. On the right is a plane W and its orthogonal complement W^\perp in \real^3.

subsection.p: The next definition places this example into a more general context.

statement.p: Given a subspace W of \real^m, the orthogonal complement of W is the set of vectors in \real^m each of which is orthogonal to every vector in W. We denote the orthogonal complement by W^\perp.

subsection.p: A typical example appears on the right of . Here we see a plane W, a two-dimensional subspace of \real^3, and its orthogonal complement W^\perp, which is a line in \real^3.
As the next activity demonstrates, the orthogonal complement of a subspace W is itself a subspace of \real^m.

statement.p:
Suppose that \wvec_1=\threevec10{-2} and \wvec_2=\threevec11{-1} form a basis for W, a two-dimensional subspace of \real^3. We will find a description of the orthogonal complement W^\perp.
Suppose that the vector \xvec is orthogonal to \wvec_1. If we write \xvec=\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3}, use the fact that \wvec_1\cdot\xvec = 0 to write a linear equation for x_1, x_2, and x_3.
Suppose that \xvec is also orthogonal to \wvec_2. In the same way, write a linear equation for x_1, x_2, and x_3 that arises from the fact that \wvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0.
If \xvec is orthogonal to both \wvec_1 and \wvec_2, these two equations give us a linear system B\xvec=\zerovec for some matrix B. Identify the matrix B and write a parametric description of the solution space to the equation B\xvec = \zerovec.
Since \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 form a basis for the two-dimensional subspace W, any vector \wvec in W can be written as a linear combination
\wvec = c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2\text{.}
If \xvec is orthogonal to both \wvec_1 and \wvec_2, use the distributive property of dot products to explain why \xvec is orthogonal to \wvec.
Give a basis for the orthogonal complement W^\perp and state the dimension \dim W^\perp.
Describe (W^\perp)^\perp, the orthogonal complement of W^\perp.

li.p: We have the equation \wvec_1\cdot\xvec = x_1 - 2x_3 = 0.
We have the equation \wvec_2\cdot\xvec = x_1+x_2 - x_3 = 0.
By distributivity, (c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2)\cdot\xvec= c_1\wvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0.
W^\perp is the solution space to the equation B\xvec=\zerovec. Therefore, a basis consists of the single vector \threevec1{-1}1, and W^\perp is one-dimensional.
Since every vector in W^\perp is orthogonal to every vector in W, the orthogonal complement of W^\perp is W.
\wvec_1\cdot\xvec = x_1 - 2x_3 = 0.
\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = x_1+x_2 - x_3 = 0.
By distributivity, (c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2)\cdot\xvec= c_1\wvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0.
A basis consists of \threevec1{-1}1, and W^\perp is one-dimensional.
The orthogonal complement of W^\perp is W.

statement.p: If L is the line defined by \vvec=\threevec1{-2}3 in \real^3, we will describe the orthogonal complement L^\perp, the set of vectors orthogonal to L.

subsection.title: The matrix transpose
subsection.p: The previous activity and examples show how we can describe the orthogonal complement of a subspace as the solution set of a particular linear system. We will make this connection more explicit by defining a new matrix operation called the transpose.

statement.p: The transpose of the m\times n matrix A is the n\times m matrix A^T whose rows are the columns of A.

This activity illustrates how multiplying a vector by A^T is related to computing dot products with the columns of A. You'll develop a better understanding of this relationship if you compute the dot products and matrix products in this activity without using technology.
If B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 4 \\ -1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix} , write the matrix B^T.
Suppose that
\vvec_1=\threevec20{-2},\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec112,\hspace{24pt} \wvec=\threevec{-2}23\text{.}
Find the dot products \vvec_1\cdot\wvec and \vvec_2\cdot\wvec.
Now write the matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} and its transpose A^T. Find the product A^T\wvec and describe how this product computes both dot products \vvec_1\cdot\wvec and \vvec_2\cdot\wvec.
Suppose that \xvec is a vector that is orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. What does this say about the dot products \vvec_1\cdot\xvec and \vvec_2\cdot\xvec? What does this say about the product A^T\xvec?
Use the matrix A^T to give a parametric description of all the vectors \xvec that are orthogonal to \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Remember that \nul(A^T), the null space of A^T, is the solution set of the equation A^T\xvec=\zerovec. If \xvec is a vector in \nul(A^T), explain why \xvec must be orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Remember that \col(A), the column space of A, is the set of linear combinations of the columns of A. Therefore, any vector in \col(A) can be written as c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2. If \xvec is a vector in \nul(A^T), explain why \xvec is orthogonal to every vector in \col(A).

li.p: Both dot products are 0 so we have A^T\xvec = \zerovec.

We need to solve the equation A^T\xvec = \zerovec so we find the reduced row echelon form A^T \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 3\\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}
The vectors orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 have the form \xvec=x_3\threevec1{-3}1.
A^T\xvec = \twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\xvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\xvec} = \twovec00 tells us that \vvec_1\cdot\xvec=0 and \vvec_2\cdot\xvec=0.

Since \xvec is orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2, we have
(c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2)\cdot\xvec = c_1\vvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\vvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0
\vvec_1\cdot\wvec =-10, \vvec_2\cdot\wvec =6.
A^T\xvec = \zerovec.
\xvec=x_3\threevec1{-3}1.
A^T\xvec = \twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\xvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\xvec} = \twovec00.
Apply the distributive property of dot products.

subsection.p: The previous activity demonstrates an important connection between the matrix transpose and dot products. More specifically, the components of the product A^T\xvec are simply the dot products of the columns of A with \xvec. We will make frequent use of this observation so let's record it as a proposition.

statement.p: If A is the matrix whose columns are \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n, then A^T\xvec = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1\cdot\xvec \\ \vvec_2\cdot\xvec \\ \vdots \\ \vvec_n\cdot\xvec \\ \end{bmatrix}

If A is the matrix A = \begin{bmatrix}\wvec_1 \amp \wvec_2\end{bmatrix} and \xvec is in W^\perp, we have
A^T\xvec = \twovec{\wvec_1\cdot\xvec}{\wvec_2\cdot\xvec} = \twovec00\text{.}
Describing vectors \xvec that are orthogonal to both \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 is therefore equivalent to the more familiar task of describing the solution set A^T\xvec = \zerovec. To do so, we find the reduced row echelon form of A^T and write the solution set parametrically as
\xvec = x_3\fourvec{-2}{1}10 + x_4\fourvec{-1}{-2}01\text{.}
Once again, the distributive property of dot products tells us that such a vector is also orthogonal to any linear combination of \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 so this solution set is, in fact, the orthogonal complement W^\perp. Indeed, we see that the vectors
\vvec_1=\fourvec{-2}110,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\fourvec{-1}{-2}01
form a basis for W^\perp, which is a two-dimensional subspace of \real^4.

subsection.p: To place this example in a slightly more general context, note that \wvec_1 and \wvec_2, the columns of A, form a basis of W. Since \col(A), the column space of A is the subspace of linear combinations of the columns of A, we have W=\col(A).

This example also shows that the orthogonal complement W^\perp = \col(A)^\perp is described by the solution set of A^T\xvec = \zerovec. This solution set is what we have called \nul(A^T), the null space of A^T. In this way, we see the following proposition, which is visually represented in .

statement.p:
For any matrix A, the orthogonal complement of \col(A) is \nul(A^T); that is,
\col(A)^\perp = \nul(A^T)\text{.}

figure.caption: The orthogonal complement of the column space of A is the null space of A^T.

subsection.title: Properties of the matrix transpose
subsection.p: The transpose is a simple algebraic operation performed on a matrix. The next activity explores some of its properties.

statement.p:
In Sage, the transpose of a matrix A is given by A.T. Define the matrices
A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ 2 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{6pt} B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -4 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{6pt} C= \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ 2 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}
Evaluate (A+B)^T and A^T+B^T. What do you notice about the relationship between these two matrices?
What happens if you transpose a matrix twice; that is, what is (A^T)^T?
Find \det(C) and \det(C^T). What do you notice about the relationship between these determinants?
Find the product AC and its transpose (AC)^T.
Is it possible to compute the product A^TC^T? Explain why or why not.
Find the product C^TA^T and compare it to (AC)^T. What do you notice about the relationship between these two matrices?
What is the transpose of the identity matrix I?
If a square matrix D is invertible, explain why you can guarantee that D^T is invertible and why (D^T)^{-1} = (D^{-1})^T.

li.p: (A+B)^T = A^T + B^T.
(A^T)^T = A.
The product A^TC^T is not defined because A^T has two columns and C^T has three rows.
We have DD^{-1} = I so (DD^{-1})^T = (D^{-1})^TD^T = I^T=I. This means that (D^T)^{-1} = (D^{-1})^T.
(A+B)^T = A^T + B^T.
(A^T)^T = A.
(AC)^T=C^TA^T.

subsection.p: In spite of the fact that we are looking at some specific examples, this activity demonstrates the following general properties of the transpose, which may be verified with a little effort.

assemblage.title: Properties of the transpose
assemblage.p:
Here are some properties of the matrix transpose, expressed in terms of general matrices A, B, and C. We assume that C is a square matrix.
If A+B is defined, then (A+B)^T = A^T+B^T.
(sA)^T = sA^T.
(A^T)^T = A.
\det(C) = \det(C^T).
If AB is defined, then (AB)^T = B^TA^T. Notice that the order of the multiplication is reversed.
(C^T)^{-1} = (C^{-1})^T.

subsection.p: There is one final property we wish to record though we will wait until to explain why it is true.

proposition.statement: For any matrix A, we have \rank(A) = \rank(A^T)\text{.}

subsection.p: This proposition is important because it implies a relationship between the dimensions of a subspace and its orthogonal complement. For instance, if A is an m\times n matrix, we saw in that \dim\col(A) = \rank(A) and \dim\nul(A) = n-\rank(A).

Now suppose that W is an n-dimensional subspace of \real^m with basis \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n. If we form the m\times n matrix A=\begin{bmatrix}\wvec_1 \amp \wvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \wvec_n\end{bmatrix}, then \col(A) = W so that
\rank(A) = \dim\col(A) = \dim W = n\text{.}

statement.p:
If W is a subspace of \real^m, then
\dim W + \dim W^\perp = m\text{.}

In , we constructed the orthogonal complement of a line in \real^3. The dimension of the orthogonal complement should be 3 - 1 = 2, which explains why we found the orthogonal complement to be a plane.
In , we looked at W, a 2-dimensional subspace of \real^5 and found its orthogonal complement W^\perp to be a 5-2=3-dimensional subspace of \real^5.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
This section introduced the matrix transpose, its connection to dot products, and its use in describing the orthogonal complement of a subspace.
The columns of the matrix A are the rows of the matrix transpose A^T.
The components of the product A^T\xvec are the dot products of \xvec with the columns of A.
The orthogonal complement of the column space of A equals the null space of A^T; that is, \col(A)^\perp = \nul(A^T).
If W is a subspace of \real^p, then
\dim W + \dim W^\perp = p.
